title: XQuery Hour
abstract:
XQuery Gotchas
Evan Lenz, MarkLogic
 
XQuery is a wonderfully productive language, especially when coupled with MarkLogic. Yet as with any language, it has its own dark corners and surprises. In this fast-paced lightning talk, we'll run through a litany of common XQuery gotchas, programming mistakes, and performance pitfalls. Many will apply to XQuery programming in general and some will be MarkLogic-specific. For each one, you'll learn the gist of the problem, the reason it fools people, and the way to avoid it. Come to commiserate. Come to preemptively save yourself time and frustration. Come to pick up tips and techniques for helping you to write faster, cleaner, and more robust code.
 
Stupid XQuery Tricks
Ron Hitchens, Overstory, Ltd.
 
This talk will take a light-hearted - yet enlightening - look at some of the clever, little known, surprising and/or infuriating aspects of XQuery. XQuery is a powerful functional language, especially with the MarkLogic extensions. But XQuery is not a procedural language like Java or C#, nor is it "SQL for XML". XQuery has its own bag of tricks and its own pitfalls. This talk will address some of the common (and amusing) newbie mistakes, some powerful XQuery idioms that are not obvious to procedural thinkers, and a bit of advanced XQuery ninja-fu. There may also be a few examples of perfectly innocent looking XQuery code that is utterly wrong. Humor yes, but also serious tips and tricks to make you a better XQuery programmer.
 
XQuery Enhancements
John Snelson, MarkLogic
 
This talk is a practical introduction to some of the XQuery enhancements John Snelson is working on for a future release of MarkLogic, including some features from XQuery 3.0. It will include real world examples of how these enhancements can be used.

While at MarkLogic, Ron also wrote Getting Started with XQuery for the Pragmatic Programmers Bookshelf. Ron has spoken nearly every year at the annual MarkLogic User Conference (as well as helping organise the first several).
